phonegame
Class GamePlayer

java.lang.Object
  phonegame.GameItem
      phonegame.MoveableGameItem
          phonegame.GamePlayer

public abstract class GamePlayer
extends MoveableGameItem

This class represents the player figure in the game. Descendants of this class need to handle the keyboard events that are responsible for the movement of the player.

Version:
2.0, October 11, 2005, 2.1, April 24, 2006, 3.0, November 17, 2006
Author:
Tim Prijn, Richard Kettelerij & Paul Bergervoet

Constructor Detail

GamePlayer

public GamePlayer()
Method Detail

fire

public abstract void fire()
Handle the FIRE key event. On a phone, this event is usually (but not always!) mapped to key 5 or a special 'softbutton'
A concrete player must always define this method, but you may leave it empty.

getMoved

public final boolean getMoved()
Ask if player has moved. Intended for use by GameEngine, to see if collision detection is needed.

Returns:
boolean indicating if player has moved

moveDown

public abstract void moveDown()
Handle the DOWN key event. On a phone, this event is usually (but not always!) mapped to key 8 or a special 'softbutton'
A concrete player must always define this method, but you may leave it empty.

moveLeft

public abstract void moveLeft()
Handle the LEFT key event. On a phone, this event is usually (but not always!) mapped to key 4 or a special 'softbutton'
A concrete player must always define this method, but you may leave it empty.

movePlayer

public final void movePlayer(int x,
                             int y)
Move the gameplayer to a new position. When you call this method from any of the methods that handle key-events (moveUp, etc.), it will trigger collision detection. If you use the method setPosition(x, y) there will be no collision detection.

Parameters:
x - the new x-position of the player
y - the new y-position of the player

moveRight

public abstract void moveRight()
Handle the RIGHT key event. On a phone, this event is usually (but not always!) mapped to key 6 or a special 'softbutton'
A concrete player must always define this method, but you may leave it empty.

moveUp

public abstract void moveUp()
Handle the UP key event. On a phone, this event is usually (but not always!) mapped to key 2 or a special 'softbutton'
A concrete player must always define this method, but you may leave it empty.

pressedButtonA

public abstract void pressedButtonA()
Handle the generic "A" gamekey event. On a phone, this event is usually (but not always!) mapped to key 1
A concrete player must always define this method, but you may leave it empty.

pressedButtonB

public abstract void pressedButtonB()
Handle the generic "B" gamekey event. On a phone, this event is usually (but not always!) mapped to key 3
A concrete player must always define this method, but you may leave it empty.

pressedButtonC

public abstract void pressedButtonC()
Handle the generic "C" gamekey event. On a phone, this event is usually (but not always!) mapped to key 7
A concrete player must always define this method, but you may leave it empty.

pressedButtonD

public abstract void pressedButtonD()
Handle the generic "D" gamekey event. On a phone, this event is usually (but not always!) mapped to key 9
A concrete player must always define this method, but you may leave it empty.
